name: Christina Williamson

summary:
Researcher in ancient history and archaeology, specializing in the Hellenistic period in Asia Minor with a focus on sacred places, landscape and state formation, and the development of civic identity. Archaeological fieldwork specialism in survey techniques and use of GIS, especially with regard to visibility analyses.

Specialties: Hellenistic period, state formation, Greek religion, archaeological surveying, GIS

name: Lucy Bennison-Chapman
position 1: Associate Scientific Editor, Social Sciences & Humanities
field of studies 1: Classical, Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies and Archaeology
skills: ['Academic Journals', 'Academic Administration', 'Academic Publishing', 'Proofreading', 'Qualitative Analysis', 'Problem Solving', 'Science Communication', 'Creativity Skills', 'Copy Editing', 'Scientific Writing', 'Teamwork', 'Presentations', 'English', 'Writing', 'Archaeology', 'Education', 'Higher Education', 'Teaching', 'Microsoft Office', 'Excavation']
summary: I am a successful researcher with a diverse, creative background. As an academic archaeologist, I have over fourteen years of research experience. Since 2005, I have worked at research institutes and archaeological projects across the Middle East (Turkey, Syria, Kuwait, Jordan), undertaking primary research, writing research reports (for government agencies, journals and the general public) contributing to multi-authored monographs and publishing original research articles for academic journals. I have presented my research at international conferences, university seminars, international research institutions and archaeological projects across the UK, Turkey and the Middle East. I am able to communicate my research to people from all backgrounds and of all ages, with a wealth of experience in public engagement activities. I have participated in various events aimed at widening participation to higher education, and directed educational activities at archaeological excavation open days. Currently working as the inaugural Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Leiden University's Netherlands Institute for the Near East (NINO); https://www.nino-leiden.nl/staffmember/dr-le-bennison-chapman.

name: Manfred (H.F.J.) Horstmanshoff
position 1: Emeritus Professor of the History of Ancient Medicine
skills: ['History', 'Ancient History', 'Lecturing', 'Literature', 'Research', 'Academic Writing', 'Teaching', 'Ancient Greek', 'Science', 'Latin', 'Publishing', 'Theory', 'University Teaching', 'Cultural Heritage', 'Philosophy', 'Archives', 'Archaeology', 'Anthropology', 'Philosophy Of Science', 'Museum Collections']
summary:
My research is centred on the history of ancient medicine in all its aspects, and at all times in its social and cultural context. Attention to the patient’s history belongs in this context. What did it mean to be ill in Graeco-Roman Antiquity? How did patients and doctors communicate? How can we grasp the different rationalities that were active in ancient medicine? I am also interested in the history of ideas. Medical anatomical and and physiological concepts, ideas and terminology play an important role as they ‘dripped down’ into literature and society up to the Early Modern Era. My main research project is patient’s history in a comparative perspective: „Seeing Patients“.

Specialties: History of Ancient Medicine
Greek and Roman Historiography

name: Stella Pekiaridi
skills: ['Translation', 'Books', 'New Media', 'Literature', 'Editing', 'Publications', 'Photography', 'Art', 'Social Media', 'Cultural Heritage', 'Proofreading', 'Journalism', 'Writing', 'Visual Arts', 'Blogging', 'Public Relations', 'Event Management', 'Strategic Communications', 'Museums', 'History']
summary:
Cultural Management:
Since 2009, I split my time between Greece and the Netherlands, being involved in the communication, project management and facilitation of various media and art projects, specializing in intercultural productions, digital platforms and offline events. In the course of the last 3 years, I have  been involved in the pre-production, the production and the post-production of audiovisual content for  Greek and Dutch media, such as documentaries, web-docs, radio & tv news broadcasts.

Occasionally, I work as a freelance art editor and curator of photo and visual media exhibitions, as well as an independent PR and communications consultant for theatres and individual artists from the fields of performing & visual arts.

Publishing Activities: 
During the last 15 years I work as a freelance translator, editor and proofreader of literature and texts relating to the Human Sciences. My main areas of specialization are Literature, History, Art History, Archeology, Museology and Visual Arts. Language Combination: EN-EL, IT-EL, IT-EN, NL-EL.

In addition, I work as a  professional reader, columnist, book reviewer and translator at various online and offline media of cultural and literary interest. Furthermore, I design and produce content for online & social media.

Academic Research: 
After the completion of my master's studies in Culture, Media and Communication with a specialization in Visual Culture my research interests  include Visual Culture Literacy as well as the use of Photography in Old and New Media. I am currently focused on representational tactics of photographic content in photobooks and exhibitions and the role of the visual document as cultural heritage.

Papers: "Our First Murder: Exhibiting Forensic Evidence outside the Police Archive",
2nd International Conference of Photography and Theory 2012 - Photography and Museums: Displayed and Displaying, Ayia Napa, Cyprus.

name: Merlijn Breunesse
field of studies 2: Ancient Greek and Latin Language and Culture
summary: I started my academic career at VU University (Amsterdam), where I obtained a Bachelor’s degree in Latin and Ancient Greek Language and Culture. Having spent a year at KU Leuven University on an Erasmus scholarship during the initial stages of my education, I decided to return to Leuven for a master's degree in Linguistics, which I obtained with a specialization in Diachronic and Comparative Linguistics in 2016. Subsequently, I joined the Friedrich-Schiller-Universität (Jena) as a Marie Curie Early Stage Researcher in the DComm project, studying for a PhD degree under the supervision of prof. Holger Diessel. In my thesis, which focused on demonstratives, I combined a typological investigation of demonstrative systems worldwide with a more in-depth study of the Latin demonstratives. Having finished my thesis, I joined the University of Amsterdam in September 2019 as a postdoctoral researcher in the Anchoring Innovation project, focusing on Latin. In my work, I aim to combine my knowledge of general linguistics and pragmatics with my passion for Ancient Greek and Latin literature.
